page.title: 04Farming in NE Wolverhampton
page.content: The farmland of the North-East edge of Wolverhampton is spread over seven small farms, whose buildings are usually old-looking, but well kept.It is bordered by the urban sprawl of several housing estates. It is also bisected by a large number of paths, lanes, main roads and a disused mineral railway. The land is well managed, being used for a mixed pattern of arable farming. Cereal crops predominate. We saw mainly barley,with some fields of wheat. Oil-seed rape is also grown and there are several fields of grass. Silage and hay are both grown for sale and to feed herds of Hereford and Friesian beef cattle. We noticed a few Charolais beef animals too. Some vegetables and potatoes are being grown but we thought it was strange that more vegatables are not grown so near to a town.
